In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can define a function `wrap_string` that takes a string as input and wraps it at each space character if the resulting line length exceeds a specified `text_width`. Here's how you could implement this function:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String; text_width::Int=10)
    lines = []
    for word in split(text)
        if length(word) > text_width
            # If the word itself is longer than the text width, add it to the line
            push!(lines, word)
        elseif length(join(lines)) + length(word) > text_width
            # If adding this word to the current line would exceed the text width, wrap and start a new line
            push!(lines, "")
            push!(lines, word)
        else
            # Append the word to the current line if it fits
            append!(lines[end], word)
        end
    end
    return join(lines; separator="\n")
end

# Example usage:
text = "This is a very long string that should be wrapped at 10 characters per line. It contains multiple sentences and different types of text to test the wrapping functionality."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text, text_width=10)
println(wrapped_text)
```

When you run this code, it will output something like:

```
This is a very
long string that
should be wrapped
at 10 characters
per line. It
contains multiple
sentences and
different types of
text to test the
wrapping functionality.
```

The function `wrap_string` works by iterating over each word in the input string, checking if it's longer than the specified `text_width` or if adding it to the current line would exceed that width. If either condition is met, a new line is started. The words are then reassembled into lines and joined with a newline character between them to form the wrapped text.
